sections.summary: Allah is praised as the absolute owner of the heavens and the earth, possessing complete knowledge of all that enters, emerges, descends, or ascends. He affirms the certainty of the **Hour** and the **Day of Account**, where every atom's weight of conduct is recorded to ensure a just recompense for believers and a painful penalty for those who undermine His revelations.

The text addresses the mockery of disbelievers regarding the **new creation** and the resurrection of the body after death. Allah points to the visible signs of the sky and the earth as a warning that His power can cause the earth to cave in or the sky to fall upon those who remain heedless.

David is granted the miracle of echoing mountains and softened iron, while Solomon is gifted control over the wind and a spring of tar. Both are commanded to work with **appreciation**, illustrating that even the most powerful prophets are servants of Allah, while the death of Solomon exposes that the jinn have no knowledge of the **unseen**.

The people of Sheba were granted two flourishing gardens but faced destruction through a flood and bitter fruits as a penalty for their **ingratitude**. This narrative serves as a lesson for the steadfast, confirming that **Satan** has no authority except to distinguish those who truly believe in the Hereafter from those in doubt [525–526].

Allah challenges those who invoke partners besides Him, asserting that these entities possess nothing in the heavens or earth and offer no **intercession** without His leave. The Prophet is identified as a universal warner, and the text emphasizes that the **appointed Day** is a fixed reality that cannot be advanced or delayed [526–527].

sections.theme: The Trial of Wealth and Arrogance
sections.summary: On the Day of Judgment, the oppressed will blame the arrogant elite for misleading them, but all will face the **retribution** of their deeds. The text clarifies that material **wealth and children** do not provide nearness to Allah; rather, only **faith and good deeds** grant the high chambers of Paradise, as Allah expands or restricts provisions according to His will [527–528].

In the final reckoning, the angels will disavow those who worshiped them, stating that the idolaters were actually following the **jinn**. The surah critiques those who reject the Truth as magic or lies, reminding them that more powerful previous nations were destroyed for their **rejection** of the messengers.

Humanity is urged to reflect individually or in pairs on the truth of the Message, acknowledging Allah as the Knower of the **Unseen**. The surah concludes with the image of disbelievers seized by terror when it is too late to believe, as a **barrier** is permanently placed between them and the desires they pursued in the worldly life [528–529].
